steps.title: Remove the turkey from the freezer and put it on a platter.
steps.content: Remove the turkey from the freezer and put it on a platter. Leave the turkey in the packaging and put it directly onto a large platter or a tray. Ensure that the turkey is positioned so the breasts are up. [1] X Research source Choose a platter with slightly raised edges or a rimmed tray. This will prevent any juice that could leak out of the package from dripping in your refrigerator.

steps.title: Thaw the turkey for 1 day per 4 pounds (1.8 kg).
steps.content: Thaw the turkey for 1 day per 4 pounds (1.8 kg). Check the turkey's weight so you know how long it will need to defrost and move the shelves in your refrigerator so you can put the turkey on the bottom shelf. Plan on defrosting the turkey for: [2] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source 1 to 3 days if it's 4 to 12 pounds (1.8 to 5.4 kg) 3 to 4 days if it's 12 to 16 pounds (5.4 to 7.3 kg) 4 to 5 days if it's 16 to 20 pounds (7.3 to 9.1 kg) 5 to 6 days if it's 20 to 24 pounds (9.1 to 10.9 kg)

steps.title: Cook
steps.content: Cook the defrosted turkey within 2 days of completely thawing it. Unlike other thawing methods, you don't need to immediately cook the turkey as soon as it's thawed. In fact, if you change your mind about cooking a turkey but you've already defrosted it, you can put it back into the freezer. [3] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source If you choose to put the turkey back into the freezer, the meat may not be as tender when you do choose to cook it.

steps.title: Unwrap the turkey and put it into a large sealable bag.
steps.content: Unwrap the turkey and put it into a large sealable bag. Discard the packaging that the turkey came in and put the turkey into a leak-proof bag. This will prevent turkey juices from leaking out and water from soaking into the turkey. [4] X Trustworthy Source FoodSafety.gov Online portal combining food safety information from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the Food Safety and Inspection Service, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Go to source

steps.title: Put the turkey into a sink and fill it with cold tap water.
steps.content: Put the turkey into a sink and fill it with cold tap water. Put the plug in the sink and place the wrapped turkey into it. Then, fill the sink with cold water so that almost all of the turkey is covered. [5] X Trustworthy Source FoodSafety.gov Online portal combining food safety information from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the Food Safety and Inspection Service, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Go to source

steps.title: Thaw the turkey for 1 hour per 2 pounds (0.91 kg).
steps.content: Thaw the turkey for 1 hour per 2 pounds (0.91 kg). Check the turkey package to see how much it weighs. Since it takes about 30 minutes to defrost 1 pound (450 g) of turkey, you'll need between 2 to 12 hours. Defrost the turkey for: [6] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source 2 to 6 hours if it's 4 to 12 pounds (1.8 to 5.4 kg) 6 to 8 hours if it's 12 to 16 pounds (5.4 to 7.3 kg) 8 to 10 hours if it's 16 to 20 pounds (7.3 to 9.1 kg) 10 to 12 hours if it's 20 to 24 pounds (9.1 to 10.9 kg)

steps.title: Change the water every 30 minutes until the turkey is defrosted.
steps.content: Change the water every 30 minutes until the turkey is defrosted. To prevent the water from becoming too warm, drain the sink and refill it with cold water every 30 minutes. Keep doing this until the turkey is completely defrosted. [7] X Trustworthy Source FoodSafety.gov Online portal combining food safety information from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the Food Safety and Inspection Service, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Go to source Remember that you can easily unwrap the turkey and feel inside the cavity to check if it's defrosted.

steps.title: Cook
steps.content: Cook the defrosted turkey immediately. As soon as you think the turkey is defrosted, transfer the turkey to a roasting pan and season it as you like. Put the turkey into a preheated oven and cook it right away. [8] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source Since you've been raising the temperature of the turkey, it's important to cook it as soon as you've defrosted it so it doesn't grow harmful bacteria.

steps.title: Read your owner's manual to decide if the turkey will fit.
steps.content: Read your owner's manual to decide if the turkey will fit. Your owner's manual will tell you what size turkey will fit in the microwave. For example, the manual might say that you can safely thaw a turkey that's up to 15 pounds (6.8 kg). If your turkey weighs more than what the manual recommends, choose a different defrosting method. [9] X Research source Check the size of your microwave to determine if the turkey will fit.

steps.title: Unwrap the turkey and put it on a microwave-safe plate.
steps.content: Unwrap the turkey and put it on a microwave-safe plate. Discard all of the packaging and remove any metal that might be wrapping the legs together. Then set the turkey on a large microwave-safe plate. [10] X Research source Ensure that the plate will fit inside your microwave.

steps.title: Defrost the turkey for 6 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg).
steps.content: Defrost the turkey for 6 minutes per 1 pound (0.45 kg). Put the turkey into the microwave and use the defrost feature. Enter the turkey's weight and start the microwave. Defrosting should take about 6 minutes for each 1 pound (450 g) of turkey. [11] X Trustworthy Source FoodSafety.gov Online portal combining food safety information from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, the Food Safety and Inspection Service, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Go to source If your turkey is over 15 pounds (6.8 kg), you may want to turn it over once or twice as it defrosts. This will help it thaw evenly.

steps.title: Remove the turkey and cook it immediately.
steps.content: Remove the turkey and cook it immediately. Since a microwave will thaw the turkey unevenly, some parts of the turkey might begin to cook. To prevent bacteria from growing, plan on cooking the turkey as soon as it's finished defrosting in the microwave. [12] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source Consider preheating your oven during the last 20 minutes the turkey is defrosting. This way you can immediately transfer the turkey to a roasting pan and put it into the hot oven.
